Any official delegation level qualifies, including military commanders, political representatives, or designated negotiators.

Sources for resolution include, but are not limited to, reports from Reuters, BBC, or Al Jazeera, UN statements, African Union announcements, or official statements from the SAF or RSF.

Sequential meetings where parties attend the same venue at different times do not qualify.

Since the release of the 'Quadrilateral International Mechanism' roadmap—comprising the U.S., Saudi Arabia, Egypt, and the UAE—in September 2024, intensive regional and international consultations have been underway to open communication channels between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). Egyptian Foreign Minister Bader Abdel Ati’s visit to Port Sudan and his meeting with Sudanese Army Commander and head of the Sovereignty Council, Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, affirmed the shared stance of the Quadrilateral, emphasizing Egypt’s efforts to end the war through international platforms, including the mechanism, to achieve a humanitarian truce and a political process leading to a Sudanese-Sudanese consensus. **Sudanese Army Chief Rejects 'Conciliation' with Rapid Support Forces**
Sudanese army chief and de facto leader Abdel Fattah al-Burhan has rejected 'conciliation' with the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) which has been waging war against them for over two years. The US is intensifying its diplomatic efforts to achieve peace in Sudan, which has been plagued by 'the worst humanitarian crisis in the world' according to the UN. In a speech marking the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the armed forces, al-Burhan reiterated his 'determination to continue the battle of dignity and defeat the rebellion and reject conciliation and compromise, no matter the cost'. This comes days after a meeting in Switzerland with US National Security Adviser for Africa, Maasoum Boulos. A Sudanese government source confirmed that al-Burhan and Boulos discussed an American proposal for a 'comprehensive ceasefire' and 'delivering humanitarian aid'. Despite US and Saudi efforts, attempts at mediation have so far failed to achieve a ceasefire in Sudan. The RSF, led by Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo, is seeking to establish a parallel administration in western Sudan in areas under its control. The UN Security Council strongly condemned this move, calling it a 'direct threat to Sudan's unity and territorial integrity'. The war that broke out in April 2023 has killed tens of thousands and displaced millions. Sudan is also facing its worst cholera outbreak in years. The EU has called on the warring parties to allow international humanitarian aid to enter the country 'as soon as possible'.

**US Mediation Efforts Fail to End Sudan War**
A new attempt at mediation to end the deadly war in Sudan has failed, with the US unable to bring together key international actors in Washington. On the ground, the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) are setting up rival governments and seeking to expand their territorial control, with fierce fighting in North Darfur and Kordofan (west). Since April 2023, the war between General Abdel Fattah al-Burhane, head of the army, and his former deputy Mohamed Daglo, also known as 'Hemedti', commander of the RSF, has killed tens of thousands of people and displaced millions, causing what the UN calls the 'worst humanitarian crisis in the world', with destruction, famine, and cholera. - Diplomatic disagreements - Several mediation initiatives have already been launched, including in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and Geneva, Switzerland, but none have succeeded. In early July, US President Donald Trump highlighted the efforts of his administration for peace in Africa. 'There is still much to be done, particularly in countries like Sudan, where there are many problems.' The US diplomacy had planned to bring together the Saudi, Egyptian, and Emirati foreign ministers, in the absence of the rival Sudanese parties. However, this quadripartite meeting was cancelled due to a disagreement between Egypt and the UAE, according to AFP information. According to a diplomatic source, the UAE had proposed, at the last minute, a text excluding both the army and the RSF from any future transition, a clause considered 'totally unacceptable' by Cairo. Additionally, 'the US were not ready because they had eliminated the personnel working on Sudan' during the recent restructuring of the State Department, which deprived them of any 'institutional memory' on the negotiation process, according to Sudanese analyst Kholood Khair. For the pro-army governor of Darfur, Mini Minawi, the diplomatic deadlock reveals a disconnect between international mediations and the realities on the ground, when it should be 'acting on the opinions expressed by the Sudanese and not by foreign countries'. 'We think that the UAE is not qualified to lead a mediation (...) because the RSF are fed and supported by the UAE,' he said on Monday. Abu Dhabi has always denied any involvement in the conflict, despite several reports by UN experts and international organizations accusing it of arming paramilitaries. Cairo, on the other hand, supports the power of General al-Burhane and considers it the only legitimate actor. - 'Absence of will' - For Bakri Eljack, spokesperson for the civil coalition Sumoud led by former Prime Minister Abdallah Hamdok, 'in the absence of a genuine internal will', it is unlikely that the US and major regional powers will achieve results. The failure of the Washington meeting 'will have no impact on the ground, as the armed forces do not attach importance to it since the situation on the ground has changed' in their favor, unlike the RSF, 'confronted with setbacks and internal divisions,' estimates military expert and former General Tarek Abdelkarim. On the other hand, Alaa Naqd, spokesperson for the Tassiss, a coalition grouping the RSF, armed movements and civil groups, estimated that the sine die postponement of the quadripartite meeting should not be interpreted 'as a failure' but as a 'first attempt by the Trump administration to deal with the Sudanese dossier.' For the Americans, it was a matter of 'sounding out the opinions of its allies in the region,' he said to AFP from Nyala, capital of South Darfur. Since a few weeks, each of the two rival camps is trying to assert its legitimacy. The recently appointed Prime Minister by the military power, Kamel Idriss, is seeking to re-establish his new government in Khartoum, the capital recaptured by the army in late May. In parallel, the RSF have also designated their own Prime Minister, Mohamed Hassan al-Ta'ayshi, and begun to form a rival administration, particularly in Darfur. The African Union has called on Tuesday not to recognize this rival government, estimating that this initiative compromises 'peace efforts and the very future of Sudan.'

**UN Security Council to Hold Open Session on Sudan Crisis**
The United Nations Security Council is set to hold an open session on Friday, June 27, to discuss the developments in the Sudan crisis. The session will be part of the regular briefings provided by the UN Secretary-General on the situation in the country, which has become one of the worst humanitarian and armed conflicts in the world in recent years. According to diplomatic sources, the Council is expected to listen to a comprehensive briefing by the UN Special Representative to Sudan, Ramadan al-Mamur, covering the latest political and humanitarian developments, as well as the challenges facing efforts to achieve a lasting ceasefire between the warring parties. The open session will be followed by closed consultations among Council members, during which they will discuss an assessment of the conflict's developments and ways to support ongoing mediation efforts at both regional and international levels. The conflict, which has entered its third year, has resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands and the displacement of over 10 million people inside and outside the country, amidst a near-total collapse of government institutions and essential services, including healthcare and education. Reports indicate an escalation of attacks on civilians and vital infrastructure, prompting dozens of humanitarian organizations to suspend or significantly reduce their activities, due to the lack of guarantees for the protection of humanitarian workers and civilian facilities. Despite the efforts of international and regional forces, including the 'Jeddah Initiative' led by the US and Saudi Arabia, as well as the efforts of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), negotiations have yet to yield tangible progress, amidst mutual accusations of obstructing peace paths and failing to adhere to a ceasefire. Observers expect the upcoming Security Council session to increase political and diplomatic pressure on the warring parties, raise the level of coordination between the UN and regional partners to push for peace efforts, and prevent further collapse in Sudan. The international community remains hopeful that the Sudanese parties will demonstrate a genuine political will to transition from a cycle of violence to a dialogue table and address the roots of the crisis comprehensively and sustainably.

**UN Security Council to Hold Open Session on Sudan Crisis**
The United Nations Security Council is expected to hold an open session on Friday, June 27, to discuss the humanitarian crisis in Sudan and listen to a briefing from the UN Secretary-General's representative, Ramadan Al-Omama. The briefing will cover the deteriorating humanitarian situation, increasing attacks on civilians, and the challenges facing peace efforts and ceasefire negotiations. This comes as Sudan is experiencing its worst crisis since independence, with the ongoing conflict between the Sudanese Armed Forces, led by General Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, and the Rapid Support Forces, led by Mohamed Hamdan Dagalo 'Hemeti', entering its third year without any significant progress towards a political solution. The conflict has resulted in a major humanitarian disaster, with tens of thousands of deaths and over 10 million people displaced internally and externally. The infrastructure and basic services, including healthcare and education institutions, have also collapsed. Despite regional and international mediation, including the 'Jeddah' track led by the US and Saudi Arabia, the negotiations have not made any tangible progress, with both sides accusing each other of obstructing solutions. As Ramadan Al-Omama said, 'The situation in Sudan is dire and requires immediate attention and action from the international community.'
